subject: Giants Crush
event:
Well, that was fun.  If only every game was like this...

(Maybe it is, if you're a Colts fan).

These were the Giants I remember.  The swarming aggressive D, the sacks, the knockdowns, the hurries, the interceptions, runners tackled at the line of scrimmage.  And on offense, long time-consuming drives ending in touchdowns.  Eli looked terrific, spreading the ball around.  Nicks, Smith, Manningham, and Boss all had big catches, and even Derek Hagan scored a touchdown.  The running game was back, especially when Ahmad Bradshaw had the ball.  The O line opened gaping holes, and the D line was so relentless that our wafer-thin secondary was never threatened.

Yeah, these were the real G-Men.

I have no idea who those clowns in the Redskins uniforms were.

That fake field goal the Skins tried at the end of the first half had to be one of the most bizarre plays I've ever seen.  Watching Steve Young talk about it in the postgame was hilarious.

I do feel sorry for Jim Zorn, whose postgame press conference was... well, obviously, no one ever taught the guy Coachspeak.  Poor guy is not long for D.C.

But it was a great win.

Now we need two more like it, coupled with a Cowboys loss.

(Or a Packers loss, maybe... but while I know the G-Men have the tiebreaker over Dallas, no one has ever mentioned who wins a tie between New York and Green Bay).

Next week, the Panthers.  Who beat the Vikings yesterday.  Let's hope the real G-Men show up.

comments.article:
Yes yes, we're quite aware that our Redskins have taken a leave of wit this past... erm... decade...

I pity Zorn too, but he lost Detroit. That's a fail so great that it is historic trivia.

I do not pity Zorn. He'll be fired and most likely paid for the rest of his contract.

I pity the person... err... sucker they get to replace him. The problem is not on the field, or in the front office. The problem is in the Corner Office.
If the three end up with the same record Giants and Cowboys are in - If Dallas is 11-5 and GB and NY 10-6 - NY is in GB out.

Not quite. The Giants would win the 3-way tie breaker by having the best record against common opponents, but then it would revert back to the 2-way tie breaker between Green Bay and Dallas. Green Bay beat Dallas head to head, so the Packers would win. So if all three teams finish with the same record, New York and Green Bay would be in and Dallas would be out.

Wow...sweet that you are a Giants and Jets fan...........fan of the Giants since I was born (75)...the Giants I remember were the tough D of LT and the 86 crew....we need to get that back...Big Blue is known for defense!

Jets are ok...I worked at the Meadowlands, so I do not hate the Jets...but am a die hard Giants fan................keep on winning, and pray for GB and Dallas losses! Love your books!
comments.subject: Giants!

comments.article: if the Giants and the Packers end up with the same W-L record, the tiebreaker for common games would come into play (Cowboys, Cardinals, Vikings, Buccaneers).  the Giants will have, at worst, a 3-2 record against those opponents, while the Pack would have, at best, a 2-3 record.  Giants would be in the playoffs.
comments.subject: re: Packers-Giants tiebreakers

comments.article:
"If New York wins it will be a game behind the Cowboys and Packers (9-5) and would own a tiebreaker on both."

This is from Micheal Silvers Morning Rush column on Yahoo.com

http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ms-morningrush122109&prov=yhoo&type=lgns

Just thought you might like to know!

Dear GRRM:
I love you, but dear GOD please stop talking about football.

*ducks*

It will likely go to results in games we have in common with the Packers, so that Vikings game will resonate loudly in our shout for the second wildcard place.

At regular season end we will both have played Dallas, Tampa, Minnesota & Arizona. They'll have played Minnesota twice and we will have played Dallas twice.

At the moment the scores are: NYG 3-1, GB 1-3. So, if we can get that game on them in these final moments we have a very good chance of that wildcard spot...

Its a very big if though. Their remaining games are against Seattle in Lambeau Field and an Arizona team that are already qualified.

I'm a huge fan of yours, GRRM, but I feel compelled to tell you that the Giants you saw tonight aren't the "Real" Giants. This is what happens when you play the Redskins, nothing more. The only quality team your boys have beat this year is Dallas, who might not even make the playoffs themselves.

I know, I know...Bills fans such as myself shouldn't talk smack. But seriously, I live in New York and now will have to listen to a week of NY media-types hyping the Giants when we all know they're pretenders.
comments.subject: Real Giants?

comments.article:
Green Bay has the tiebreaker due to conference record (and no head-to-head).

Green Bay's remaining games: Seattle, @Arizona (with AZ having nothing to play for).

NY Giants' remaining games: Carolina, @Minnesota (with MINN having nothing to play for, most likely).

Dallas, even with their better conference record, is ranked below the Giants in three-way tiebreakers due to their head-to-head record, even if their record is the same. Teams are seeded in three-way conference tiebreakers by their ranking within their division.

TO SUM UP:
Giants need:

Dallas loses one game and the Giants win both then Giants are in;

If Dallas and NYG win out, and Green Bay loses one game then:
1. both Giants and GB are 8-4 in conference
2. Giants win tiebreaker due to Giants having better record against common opponents (Giants 3-1 because they will have to beat Minnesota regardless, Packers 2-2, assuming Packers beat Cardinals); or

If Packers lose both and the Giants lose to Minnesota:
1. both Giants and GB are 7-5 in conference
2. Giants win tiebreaker with Giants being 2-2 in common games and Packers being 1-3 in common games

Get it? Got it? Good! - a line from a very funny movie, btw.
comments.subject: tiebreakers

comments.article: The only way Green Bay loses to Seattle is turnovers.  Right now, the Seahawks couldn't beat a college team.  The GM Ruskell is out, and Mora's next.  The team quit playing football after pulling out a great game against SF.  The past two weeks have been pathetic; not just on the play on the field but practically every coaching decision has been horrible. Look for Rogers to throw for 300 yards and Grant to run for 150.  I predict about 38-7 Packers.  AZ is a different story.  They won't want to give away a game to GB that could be a future playoff matchup.
comments.subject: Re: tiebreakers

comments.article:
Option 1: The Giants will clinch a wild card by winning their remaining three games AND if either Dallas OR Green Bay loses one of their final two games.

Why? The three teams would be thrust into a three-way tie at 10-6. In this scenario, The Giants would get the fifth playoff seed (which as of this writing would draw Arizona) because the Giants beat Dallas in the head-to-head tie-breaker AND they also edge Green Bay in the common opponent tie-breaker, which comes after conference record which if given this scenario, both Green Bay and the Giants would be tied at 8-4.

Ok, so let’s remember that Dallas, New York and Green Bay’s remaining games are against NFC teams. If option one were to occur, the Giants’ common opponents with Green Bay are Minnesota, Tampa, Dallas and Arizona. Three straight Giants wins would give New York a 3-1 record over common opponents while the best Green Bay can hope to finish is 2-2 (they still need to play Arizona). Moreover, if the three teams have the same record by the season’s end, Dallas is eliminated because of the head-to-head tiebreaker.

Option 2: The Giants will clinch a wild card by winning two of their remaining three games AND if either Dallas OR Green Bay loses their two remaining games.
comments.subject: Giants' Playoff Hopes

comments.article: The interceptions in the third and fourth quarters might as well have been giftwrapped for Christmas! Congrats on the win.

Currently the Packers hold the edge over the Giants - obviously in a better overall record, but also with a better conference record. Both teams have two more conference games.

TO BREAK A TIE FOR THE WILD-CARD TEAM http://www.nfl.com/standings/tiebreakingprocedures

If it is necessary to break ties to determine the two Wild-Card clubs from each conference, the following steps will be taken.

1. If the tied clubs are from the same division, apply division tie breaker.
2. If the tied clubs are from different divisions, apply the following steps.

Two Clubs

1. Head-to-head, if applicable.
2. Best won-lost-tied percentage in games played within the conference.
3. Best won-lost-tied percentage in common games, minimum of four.
4. Strength of victory.
5. Strength of schedule.
6. Best combined ranking among conference teams in points scored and points allowed.
7. Best combined ranking among all teams in points scored and points allowed.
8. Best net points in conference games.
9. Best net points in all games.
10. Best net touchdowns in all games.
11. Coin toss.


As for common opponents, the only ones I see are Dallas and Tampa, so it doesn't meet the required FOUR. I don't know about Strength of Victory/Schedule, but the Packers have a MUCH better PF/PA at +100 to the Giants +44.
As a Colts fan, I can assure you that they haven't had that many romps this year.  Of the 14 victories, 7 required a fourth quarter comeback.
The Panthers are kinda having a reorganizing year it seems, so you're probably in there.

Speculation of the local sports commentators is that the fake field goal was a middle finger to Snyder.

I didn't watch the game, we all quit about mid-season.

comments.upictitle: Rum, Sodomy, and the Lash: Pick Two: monkey pirate
comments.article: I sincerely hope it is the Eagles who give you your Cowboys defeat!
football is meaningless and full of pain.

George,

Giants get in over the Packers in a tiebracker due to wins over common opponents.

comments.upictitle: Random Writings: Enter At Own Risk
comments.article:
I was playing around with the Yahoo Playoffs Scenarios page. It's a little flash app that lets you muck around with the remaining games to see how the playoffs would change based on different scenarios.

If Dallas, New York and Green Bay win out, the G-Men are left out looking in. If NY and GB win out, but Dallas loses either remaining game, the Giants get in. If NY and Dallas win out, but GB drops a game, then the Giants also get in.

There are a few crazy variations, involving Dallas and GB losing out, that also get the Giants in (so long as they win one out of two), but that doesn't seem likely.

Under what I think is the most likely scenario, all three teams in the hunt win next week (Dallas over Washington, GB over Seattle, Giants over Carolina). In Week 17, the Giants must beat Minnesota, then hope that Philly beats the Cowboys or GB falls to Arizona. If that happens, they are in.

So it's possible, but we need help.

The AFC is a complete mess. After this week's games, things will become clearer. A bunch of the 7-7 teams have critical games that will eliminate some of them for sure. I was playing around with those scenarios for about an hour last night. Here's a link if you're interested:

http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/playoffscenario
Giants have the tiebreaker against Green Bay. So if the Giants win out and either the Cowboys or Packers lose one, they're in.

The Giants also have the tiebreaker against the Packers.  So if they finish tied with either the Cowboys or the Packers, they're in.  And if all three times finish in a three-way tie, the Giants are still in.

George,

As a die-hard Packers fan, you made me look it up. We just don't know enough yet to determine who would win a GB-NYG tie. Here's how it would play out:

Two Clubs
1. Head-to-head, if applicable.
2. Best won-lost-tied percentage in games played within the conference.
3. Best won-lost-tied percentage in common games, minimum of four.
4. Strength of victory.
5. Strength of schedule.
6. Best combined ranking among conference teams in points scored and points allowed.
7. Best combined ranking among all teams in points scored and points allowed.
8. Best net points in conference games.
9. Best net points in all games.
10. Best net touchdowns in all games.
11. Coin toss.

Three or More Clubs
(Note: If two clubs remain tied after third or other clubs are eliminated, tie breaker reverts to step 1 of applicable two-club format.)
1. Apply division tie breaker to eliminate all but the highest ranked club in each division prior to proceeding to step 2. The original seeding within a division upon application of the division tie breaker remains the same for all subsequent applications of the procedure that are necessary to identify the two Wild-Card participants.
2. Head-to-head sweep. (Applicable only if one club has defeated each of the others or if one club has lost to each of the others.)
3. Best won-lost-tied percentage in games played within the conference.
4. Best won-lost-tied percentage in common games, minimum of four.
5. Strength of victory.
6. Strength of schedule.
7. Best combined ranking among conference teams in points scored and points allowed.
8. Best combined ranking among all teams in points scored and points allowed.
9. Best net points in conference games.
10. Best net points in all games.
11. Best net touchdowns in all games.
12. Coin toss

Cheers,
-Dave
comments.subject: Tie Breakers

comments.article: Yup. The Packers will clinch a birth this weekend with a win over Seattle and either a Dallas or New York Loss.
comments.subject: Re: Tie Breakers

comments.article:
Congrats to the G-Men! It's always great to see a storied franchise not run by Dan Snyder or Jerry Jones do well.

As for the Jets, we Colts fans apologize in advance for what will likely unfold during Sunday's game at Lucas Oil Stadium. No offense, your beloved Jets are just a speedbump....

On a positive note, I hear that pain and agony are always useful in writing big epic novels, so maybe that dreaded "knot" can finally be undone! ;)
comments.subject: Colts Fan

comments.article: Zorn is an asshat. I'm glad your Giants won.

Being a longtime Seahawks fan, I have a soft spot in my heart for Jim Zorn (star QB, then QB coach for the Hawks).

I hope he is able to learn from all this 'Skins experience and grow as a coach.
